comment.author: 75354144@N07
comment._content: I know the girl sitting on the ground at the front is my grandmother Nell Long, a singer, and the photo was probably taken in Waterford where she lived. The man second from the right is Mr. Bor, later to  become famous under his stage name as the actor Max Adrian. Unfortunately I don't have any information as to who the Humming Birds were!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/75354144@N07] Joan, I am not joking with you, but you have made my day, week, month with this information! It has driven me mad that we couldn't identify anybody in this one.

So, we have your grandmother, Nell Long. I'm assuming she's dead? Was she an amateur or professional singer? And do you know where she lived?

Delighted about Mr. Bor, because he sounded so exotic, I'd always assumed he was their Svengali/Manager and had commissioned the photo but wasn't actually in it himself...

Thank you so much! You've made an old library very happy...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75354144@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
Glad I was able to help. Yes my granny died in Oct 92. She was a professional singer and lived in John's Hill, Waterford City and then in Tramore, Co. Waterford.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75354144@N07] Brilliant to have this extra info to add above, thank you again!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75549898@N02
comment._content:
Ellen Millicent Long, was born in June 1908, to William Joseph (Commissioner for Oaths in Waterford), originally from Co Tipperary and Alice (formerly Aldred of Lancashire).  Nell, as she came to be known, had two other sisters, Alice Mary (fondly known as Bunty) and Wendy and a step sister, Maureen (from William's first marriage to an Emily Kate, who sadly died in childbirth) who must have been born in 1902, judging from the 1911 census.  The family were very involved in the 'light opera' scene in the 20s+, in Waterford.  
No information about 'Ted' Paxton has been forthcoming.  The couple married shortly after this picture was taken and moved to Scotland.  Nell had three children, Peter, Timothy and Millicent, 10 grandchildren and many great grandchildren.  The family moved back to Waterford, when Millicent was approx two and a half years old.  Judith Whitton nee Paxton

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75549898@N02] Thank you! Really delighted to hear more about your family! I'm wondering about two other photos in our collections. Could William Joseph Long have something to do with this one, if he was known as Willie Long also? And this one is titled: Mr John Heaslip, c/o Miss Nellie Long, wedding group.??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75592368@N07
comment._content: Fantastic to see the concert party photo! I'm writing a non-fiction book which touches on Concert party ( skit and song)  folk who came to live and work here. Found out the other day that that whole "pierrot' /  ( and later Concert Party) scene in UK ( the "Good Companions" kind of shows) actually started in the late 19th century in our own seaside town of Bray. It seems a UK performer with a particular vision ( very particular, you'd have to say, looking at the folks above; ) ) got hired by Bray Council for an outdoor gig there, dressed like a Commedia del Arte clown, took the idea back to the U.K, and it took off like wildfire! Which is not a thing you'd wish to see anywhere near those Humming birds costumes. Great, great picture - I may be back in touch about it for my book! Whole flickr stream is fantastic!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75592368@N07] Fascinating about Bray! Do indeed get in touch about your book, and we have plenty of other material that would be really useful for you besides photos - playbills, etc. And thanks for the compliment...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
